instruction: What is RIS?
output: RIS is the Research Infrastructure Services team within WashU IT.

instruction: Who are RIS Services for?
output: RIS services are for WashU faculty and staff, focused on the research mission of WashU.

instruction: Where can I get help with WUSTL Keys?
output: https://it.wustl.edu/home/how-to/wustl-connect/

instruction: What is the address of the RIS datacenter?
output: 222 S Newstead Ave. St. Louis, MO 63110

instruction: How do I get help with the RIS Compute Service?
output: Please visit the RIS Service Desk for help with RIS Compute: https://ris.wustl.edu/support/service-desk/

instruction: Where can I find RIS Compute Documentation?
output: The RIS User Manual has a chapter for the Compute Service.

instruction: How do I contact RIS?
output: Visit this link to learn about ways to contact us: https://ris.wustl.edu/about-us/contact-us/

instruction: Where can I find the RIS User Manual?
output: The RIS User Manual can be found here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/index.html

instruction: How do I make it so I can log in to RIS compute without having to use my password?
output: We suggest you make use of SSH keys to log into the compute clients, see SSH Key-Pair Setup.

instruction: Give me some resources for docker.
output: Check out our docker workshop here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/workshops/ris-docker-workshop.html

instruction: Where can I find a list of RIS-Vetted Application Containers?
output: Check out this page: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ris-vetted-compute-apps.html

instruction: Show me where to find a list of RIS-Supported Application Containers?
output: You can find a list of RIS-Supported Application Containers here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ris-supported-containers.html

instruction: Give me some resources for Software Development Best Practices.
output: Below are some links to what are considered some of the software best practices and should be kept in mind while developing.  https://distantjob.com/blog/software-engineering-best-practices/  https://www.classicinformatics.com/blog/a-handbook-to-successful-software-development-practices  https://www.tiempodev.com/blog/software-development-best-practices/  https://www.techicy.com/best-practices-for-software-development-to-follow-in-2021.html

instruction: Give me some resources for Debugging Best Practices.
output: Below are some links to information about debugging. Something necessary for software development.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debugging  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubber_duck_debugging  https://jonskeet.uk/csharp/debugging.html  https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/debugging-tips-to-get-better-at-it/  https://blog.hartleybrody.com/debugging-code-beginner/

instruction: Tell me about File Naming Best Practices
output: File names should be precise as NTFS file name size has a limit of 255 characters. This is a hard limit of the system that the Storage/Compute platform uses. Files to be transferred to Storage/Compute need to be created following this.

instruction: Is there a GUI based system for using the RIS Scientific Compute Platforms?
output: Yes, check out our guide on Open On Demand, a GUI based system for using the Scientific Compute Platforms: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html

instruction: How do I get started with RIS Services?
output: It is assumed that users will be research faculty and staff and have Wash U WUSTL Key IDs, have access to Wash U IT Networks. With these as pre-requisites, one can request new services by creating a Service Desk Request.

instruction: Can I access RIS compute services off campus?
output: Yes, however you will need to use a VPN to access compute1. Head over to https://it.wustl.edu/items/connect/ for further instructions.

instruction: How do I login to RIS compute services?
output: The compute service uses the SSH protocol to one of several numbered access points with names like compute1-client-N, where N is a number. Here is an example of connecting to client-1: ssh wustlkey@compute1-client-1.ris.wustl.edu

instruction: I want to look at the User Agreement Policies for RIS
output: Here are the User Agreement Policies: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/policies-user-agreement.html

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: A subscription tier is associated with a number of resources that are guaranteed for use based on the tier.

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: A condo queue is a queue associated with a purchased condo. More information about condos can be found here: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/compute/compute-condo/

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: The general queue runs batch jobs much like the traditional HPC setting. They run in the background in the queue system. The general queue also makes use of cache system, which you can learn more about here. Jobs in the general queue can run for up to 28 days.

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: The general-interactive queue runs jobs interactively so that you can interact directly with them or watch a job. The general-interactive queue does not use the cache system and instead interfaces with the Storage Platform directly. Jobs in the general-interactive queue can run for up to 24 hours.

instruction: How do I view active jobs on RIS compute1?
output: Type bjobs in the command line, or click Active Jobs in the Open OnDemand GUI for RIS.

instruction: Can I assign priority to the execution of my jobs on RIS Compute?
output: Yes. Use the -sp flag to set a numeric priority to the execution of your jobs. You can modify the priority of jobs in a pending state by using bmod -sp.

instruction: I have a large amount of jobs on RIS compute that are similar. How can I manage them?
output: When submitting a lot of similar jobs, they should submitted as an array. This allows you to easily submit and manage all of the jobs as a single entity. A single LSF bsub command is used to submit and can be altered with a single command as well. Each job in the array can also be accessed and modified individually if necessary.

instruction: How do I submit jobs on RIS Compute as an array?
output: To submit one thousand jobs as a single job array called myArray, you would issue the following command: bsub -J 'myArray[1-1000]' SCRIPT.

instruction: How do I cancel a running job on RIS Compute?
output: Use the bkill command, along with the job ID. Running bkill 0 kills all of your jobs.

instruction: How do I pause a running job on RIS Compute?
output: Jobs can be stopped using bstop and later resumed with bresume.

instruction: Does RIS offer Docker containers or a repository for them?
output: RIS offers RIS hosted and controlled Docker images. You can find them here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ris-supported-containers.html   RIS also offers a list of vetted applications where we do not control the Docker image nor host it. You can find that list here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ris-vetted-compute-apps.html

instruction: Can RIS help me debug my software?
output: We strive to provide help with software debugging and support to the best of our abilities and time. With that being said, there may be times when we cannot solve an issue related to a specific piece of software or script that is not supported by RIS. In those cases, we will attempt to provide a solution to the problem, but we cannot guarantee that the solution will be successful.

instruction: What are some job execution options and examples for RIS Compute?
output: Refer to our job execution examples page: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/job-execution-examples.html

instruction: What are some ways I can access data in the RIS storage service?
output: At this time, you can access storage service via SMB mounts from MacOS, Linux, and Windows, Globus Data Transfer endpoints, and POSIX filesystem access within RIS compute.

instruction: How do I change my password for RIS compute?
output: Since RIS Compute Services uses WUSTL Key credentials you must change your password for that. Wash U IT has documentation on resetting WUSTL Key passwords: https://connect.wustl.edu/selfservice/SECURE/ChangePassword.aspx

instruction: What does it mean to have a RIS Compute Condo(minium)
output: Faculty members may purchase dedicated hardware for their labs to form what we refer to as a “condominium”. In this model, a “condo” is formed out of a set of hardware that we put into a Host Group. Then we create a pair of Queues named after the Lab, eg labname and labname-interactive. Then we create an AD group named compute-labname and populate it with Users. That group then gets priority access to that lab.

instruction: How much space is in my RIS Compute $HOME directory?
output: $HOME directories are limited to 10GB. If you wish to observe your quota, you can use the following command: mmlsquota --block-size auto -u wustlkey cache1-fs1:home1

instruction: Why is RIS Compute $HOME limited to 10G? Can I have more?
output: User $HOME directories are intended to allow space for users to make use of the compute cluster, with the knowledge that the Storage Cluster is where data and software will be stored. This is accessed via /storage1, and the Scratch Cluster is accessed via /scratch1. The $HOME directory is NOT backed up and important data should NOT be stored here. Anything you wish to be backed up should be placed in /storage1, this includes scripts.

instruction: How do I see what is using up all of my RIS Compute $HOME space?
output: You can use the following command to list out the top 10 (or any number if you replace the 10) files or directories using the most space in your $HOME directory. Make sure the following command is run from your $HOME directory: du -hsx .[^.]* * 2>/dev ull | sort -rh | head -10

instruction: Why am I getting a Disk I/O error on RIS?
output: This error typically refers to the ability of the job to write a file to a directory. The most common source of the error is a user’s home directory being full. If you encounter this error, please follow the steps below.  Use the methods described in the home directory space section section to determine if the home directory is at cap.  Remove or move files from the home directory to reduce usage.  Attempt to run the job again.  If the problem persists, submit a ticket to the service desk: https://ris.wustl.edu/support/service-desk/

instruction: How do I share files in my storage with colleagues using RIS services?
output: You can request access be granted to your colleagues through our ticketing system: https://jira.wustl.edu/servicedesk/customer/portal/2/group/7. You can also use collections within Globus to share specific folders or files with colleagues. This method is the suggested method when it comes to colleagues outside of WashU. You can find more information about using this feature here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/storage/globus.html

instruction: Why should I use Open On Demand to access RIS compute?
output: Here are a few reasons why Open On Demand is beneficial.  Users can use a web browser to access the RIS Compute Platform.  Users can use any number of supported applications or incorporate their own.  Users can navigate the RIS Compute Platform and their computing needs in a GUI instead of via the command line.

instruction: What are the current included applications for RIS Open On Demand?
output: Jupyter Notebook, Matlab, RStudio, and Relion3

instruction: Where can I find the complete documentation for RIS Open On Demand?
output: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/compute-ood.html

instruction: Where can I learn more about Condo and Subscription services for compute?
output: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/lsf-queues.html

instruction: How can I generate key files for SSH?
output: For Linux/Unix/MacOS, use the ssh-keygen command: ssh-keygen -f ~/.ssh/id_rsa_compute

instruction: How do I group jobs together on RIS Compute?
output: Create a job group with a limit of N running jobs: bgadd -L N /${compute_username}/${group_name}

instruction: How do I check the status of jobs in the LSF compute group?
output: bjgroup -s /${compute_username}/${group_name}

instruction: What is an LSF compute group?
output: A compute group is required for launching a job. RIS mediates access to services by compute groups, and you will be unable to submit a job if you are not part of one. You can find out what groups you are in by running: groups.

instruction: I am not sure how to run a job on RIS compute. Can you give me an example?
output: After you connect to the compute1 environment, launching the following job will run the date command using an alpine docker image: bsub -Is -q general-interactive -a 'docker(alpine)' date

instruction: What is a container?
output: A container consists of an entire runtime environment: an application, plus all its dependencies, libraries and other binaries, and configuration files needed to run it, bundled into one package. By containerizing the application platform and its dependencies, differences in OS distributions and underlying infrastructure are managed. RIS compute1 uses Docker to manage containers.

instruction: What is LSF?
output: LSF is an IBM management platform that includes a job scheduler and is designed for high performance computing.

instruction: How do I access features of the docker application like the docker wrapper in RIS Compute?
output: Features of the docker application (a.k.a. the docker wrapper) are accessed by setting environment variables before executing bsub: LSF_DOCKER_OPTION_1=value LSF_DOCKER_OPTION_2='value with spaces' bsub ...

instruction: What are some Docker wrapper environment variables I can change for RIS Compute?
output: Check out documentation here on variables and what they do for the Docker wrapper environment: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/docker-wrapper-env-vars.html

instruction: How do I know what WashU Network I or my lab is on?
output: The RIS team supplies a Speedtest application that will report the IP address of the browsing computer. Visit the Speedtest URL: https://speedtest.ris.wustl.edu/

instruction: Where can I find RIS Storage and Archive policies?
output: Policies can be found here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ris-compute-storage-volumes.html

instruction: I'm having trouble maintaining a stable connection to my RIS storage allocation. What can I do?
output: For help troubleshooting your connection to RIS Storage, visit: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/storage/storage-troubleshooting.html

instruction: How do I perform a connection test to the RIS storage service on Windows?
output: Use the following command to perform a connection test: Test-NetConnection -Port 445 -InformationLevel 'Detailed' -ComputerName 'storage1.ris.wustl.edu'. A result of TcpTestSucceeded : True indicates that a network connection to the storage service succeeded.

instruction: How do I perform a connection test to the RIS storage service on Mac/Linux?
output: Open a terminal and enter the command to perform a connection test to the storage service: nc -vz storage1.ris.wustl.edu 445.

instruction: What is RIS Archive Storage?
output: Archive storage is intended for long term data retention and NOT data that needs to be accessed regularly. Data moved to Archive resides on tape. Data being moved to Archive should be compressed via tar.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: Early-access features are limited to a closed group of testers for a limited subset of launches. Participation is by invitation only. These features may be unstable, change in backward-incompatible ways, and are not guaranteed to be released. There are no SLAs provided and no technical support obligations.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: Alpha is a limited-availability test before releases are cleared for more widespread use. Our focus with alpha testing is to verify functionality and gather feedback from a limited set of customers. Typically, alpha participation is by invitation and subject to pre-general-availability terms. Alpha releases don’t have to be feature complete, no SLAs are provided, and there are no technical support obligations. However, alphas are generally suitable for use in test environments.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: At beta, products or features are ready for broader customer testing and use. There are no SLAs or technical support obligations in a beta release unless otherwise specified in product terms or the terms of a particular beta program.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: General availability products and features are open to all customers, covered by the RIS SLAs, and are ready for production use.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: Deprecated features are scheduled to be shut down and removed.

instruction: What is the cost of using RIS Scientific Compute?
output: There are varying cost models with different rates. For a complete rate sheet, check out: https://wustl.app.box.com/s/dwmwgnpctqeqjhxanfi4e5yw24626zmx

instruction: What is the cost of using RIS Data Storage Platform?
output: There are varying cost models with different rates per TB of Storage. Check: https://wustl.app.box.com/s/flqip0b0npzqqoopzv72k86m01bp3pc0 for the complete rates.

instruction: Are there Office Hours available for one on one help with RIS Services?
output: Yes, RIS offers virtual office hours via zoom that can be booked at: https://ris.wustl.edu/support/

instruction: Where can I find announcements and updates on RIS Services?
output: Follow the RIS twitter: https://twitter.com/RIS_Washu_IT

instruction: How do I find events and upcoming workshops for RIS Services?
output: Click on the following link to learn more about upcoming events and workshops: https://ris.wustl.edu ews-and-events/

instruction: Where can I find previous workshop recordings and resources for RIS Services?
output: Check out this link for all previously recorded workshops and resources: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184256017/Compute+Workshops

instruction: Is it possible to tour the RIS Research Data Center?
output: RIS offers virtual and in-person tours by appointment: https://ris.wustl.edu/about-us/tours/

instruction: Where can I find information about RIS Hirings?
output: https://ris.wustl.edu/about-us/join-our-team/

instruction: Tell me about RIS partners and affiliations
output: Washington University is home to a strong, diverse research community that participates in research across the country and the world. Our community extends to a variety of partners, and whether it’s a long-term project or a short-term experiment, WashU is always open to new opportunities and breakthroughs in new knowledge through new partnerships. Visit: https://ris.wustl.edu/partners/ to learn more.

instruction: What is WUSTL Secure Enclave?
output: The WUSTL Secure Enclave service is designed to support the Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC) (inclusive of NIST Special Publication 800-171) framework defined by the Department of Defense as a way to verify compliance to protect Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI). Click here to learn more: https://ris.wustl.edu/controlled-unclassified-information/

instruction: What is Globus?
output: Globus provides a secure, unified interface to your research data. Use Globus to fire and forget high-performance data transfers between systems within and across organizations. Visit: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/applications/globus/ to learn more

instruction: What can I do with Globus?
output: Transfer data, Share data with others and develop applications and gateways. Visit: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/applications/globus/ to learn more

instruction: What is RIS Knowledge Base?
output: The RIS group curates a list of knowledge base (KB) articles which allows for self-support and faster resolution to common issues. Visit: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/overview

instruction: How do I check the status of RIS Compute and Storage Services?
output: https://itstatus.wustl.edu/

instruction: What is WashU ELN
output: WashU ELN or WashU Electronic Lab Notebook is a RIS supported application to manipulate data. Check out https://ris.wustl.edu/services/applications/washu-eln-labarchives/ to learn more.

instruction: Does RIS offer support for REDCap?
output: Yes, check out: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/applications/redcap/ to learn more

instruction: What are some general features / specifications of RIS Compute hardware?
output: RIS Compute is powered by a base system of 5,000 Intel Cascade Lake Cores, 120 NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPUs, a 300TB DDN high-performance scratch space, and a 100Gbit Mellanox HDR Network.

instruction: What is a Compute Condo?
output: Faculty members or groups of faculty members can purchase Compute Condos — dedicated hardware for their labs to form what we refer to as a condominium. Visit https://ris.wustl.edu/services/compute/compute-condo/ to learn more.

instruction: What is the Active Tier for RIS Storage?
output: The Active Tier of RIS Storage is ideal for daily use of all types of data. Perks include 5TB of free Active Storage per faculty, backups of all data, daily snapshots retained for 90 days, and high availability. For more information visit: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/research-storage/active-tier/

instruction: What is the Archive Tier for RIS Storage?
output: The Archive Tier of RIS Storage allows direct access to data, and is a good option for infrequently accessed data. Perks include near line and direct user access to data, ability to easily move data to your active tier, and a double copy of data supported by tape and disks. For more information, visit: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/research-storage/archive-tier/

instruction: What is the General Access Option for RIS Scientific Compute?
output: General Access generally is for jobs which are scheduled in a best effort fashion as resources are available, and includes general support for student researchers and post-docs, no faculty sponsor required, but has no resource guarantees, and lower priority and job limits.

instruction: What is the Subscription Model for RIS Scientific Compute?
output: The Subscription Model comes with the ability to pre-pay for compute per month in advance and receive priority access to available resources, dedicated group membership, increased job limits, and guaranteed job scheduling SLAs.

instruction: What is the Consumption Model for RIS Scientific Compute?
output: The Consumption Model allows users to pay for on-demand access to compute resources, and comes with dedicated group membership, and increased job limits.

instruction: Tell me about what RIS Consulting can do for me
output: RIS provides consulting and engagement services that can help researchers navigate the complex list of services and technologies available at the University. The RIS team can bring a diverse skill set with years of technology and research experience to facilitate your project or solve a complex technical problem. Request assistance here: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/consulting-and-engagement/

instruction: What is RIS ITSM
output: RIS ITSM is currently under development. At completion, it will allow researchers or designated roles access to billing, provisioning and change management services.

instruction: How do I transfer data in and out of RIS Compute?
output: There are a few supported methods, including Globus, Rclone, and submitting a job using a data transfer tool such as rsync, wget, curl, and scp.

instruction: How do I access RTM for RIS?
output: You can access RTM for the RIS Compute Platform at the following link: https://compute1-rtm-1.ris.wustl.edu/cacti/index.php

instruction: What is RTM for RIS?
output: RTM is an operational dashboard for IBM Spectrum LSF environments that provides comprehensive workload monitoring, reporting, and management.

instruction: How do I activate my RIS Storage Allocation?
output: Visit the RIS Service Desk, then navigate to the Storage Platform section, and begin a Service Request for a new allocation by selecting activate.

instruction: What is the SMB Protocol for RIS Storage?
output: The SMB Protocol stands for Server Message Block, and it is a network protocol used by Windows-based computers that allows systems within the same network to share files. Visit: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255947/Access+Control to learn more

instruction: How do I connect to RIS Storage from MacOS?
output: For step by step instructions, visit: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255952/Connecting+to+Storage+from+MacOS

instruction: How do I connect to RIS Storage from Windows?
output: For step by step instructions, visit: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255941/Connecting+to+Storage+from+Windows

instruction: How do I connect to RIS Storage from Linux?
output: For step by step instructions, visit: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255945/Connecting+to+Storage+from+Linux

instruction: Is there a way to summarize usage statistics for RIS Compute?
output: As of writing, this service is being developed.

instruction: How do I request more resources for my RIS Compute job?
output: Requesting more resources for your job means using options that are part of the bsub command. You can find out more information about the bsub options at the following link: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255619/Job+Execution+Examples#JobExecutionExamples-JobExecutionExamples

instruction: How long can RIS Compute jobs run in the general queue?
output: In the general queue, jobs can run for up to 28 days.

instruction: How long can RIS Compute jobs run in the general-interactive queue?
output: In the interactive queue, jobs can run for up to 24 hours.

instruction: When should I use RIS Compute's general queue?
output: Usually, the general queue is for running jobs with large amount of resource requirements. The general queue is for running large numbers of jobs, especially the same analysis on multiple samples. The general queue is NOT for GUI related software or interactive sessions.

instruction: When should I use RIS Compute's general-interactive queue?
output: Usually, the general-interactive queue is for running interactive jobs, such as GUI related software, and software and script development. The general-interactive queue is NOT for jobs that require large amounts of resource requirements, or multiple jobs running the same analysis on multiple samples.

instruction: Tell me about RIS Compute Subscription queue Tier 1
output: A subscription tier is associated with a number of resources that are guaranteed for use based on the tier. As a Tier 1 subscriber, you get access to 25 vCPUs and 1 GPU.

instruction: Tell me about RIS Compute Subscription queue Tier 2
output: A subscription tier is associated with a number of resources that are guaranteed for use based on the tier. As a Tier 2 subscriber, you get access to 50 vCPUs and 2 GPUs.

instruction: Tell me about RIS Compute Subscription queue Tier 3
output: A subscription tier is associated with a number of resources that are guaranteed for use based on the tier. As a Tier 3 subscriber, you get access to 100 vCPUs and 3 GPUs.

instruction: What happens if I go over the guaranteed resources for my RIS Compute Subscription queue Tier?
output: If you go over on the number of guaranteed vCPUs for a job submitted in this queue type, your job will not be guaranteed to run. If you go over on the number of guaranteed GPUs for a job, your job will stay in pending and never run.

instruction: What information do I need to request a new RIS storage allocation?
output: It will be necessary to indicate your WorkDay Cost Center Number, the storage amount you would like to request, an access list containing WUSTL Key IDs, and you will be asked to indicate if you intend to store protected data.

instruction: What are RIS Storage Snapshots?
output: Within the “Active” storage tier there is a directory named “.snapshots” that contains one week of daily snapshots of the Active storage space. If files in your Active space get overwritten, corrupted, or mistakenly deleted, you can copy previous versions out of the .snapshots directory back into Active.

instruction: What are RIS Storage Tape Backups?
output: Integrated into the storage environment is a high performance and scalable tape robot that manages a tape library of 18 petabytes, which allows the shuttling of data from live disk to much less expensive tape and back again on demand.

instruction: What is the basic RIS Storage layout?
output: There are 2 directories within the filesystem upon creation, Active and Snapshots. Upon enabling archive, the Archive directory will appear.

instruction: How do I manage access control to my RIS Storage allocation?
output: Please visit: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255947/Access+Control to learn more about storage access control.

instruction: How do I use Globus to access RIS Storage?
output: Check out https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255943/Installing+and+Using+Globus+Connect+Personal for a step by step guide on how to use Globus.

instruction: How do I use CHPC with smbclient to transfer data to RIS Storage?
output: Check out https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255814/Moving+Data+From+CHPC+with+smbclient for a step by step guide.

instruction: How do I recover data from my snapshot in RIS Storage?
output: There are a few ways to restore data from your RIS Storage Snapshot. Check out: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255928/Recovering+Data+From+Snapshots for more details.

instruction: Who can use WashU ELN?
output: WashU ELN is available to current WashU students, faculty, staff, researchers and PIs.

instruction: How much does WashU ELN cost?
output: WashU ELN is University-funded and available at no cost to the WashU community.

instruction: Where is WashU ELN data stored?
output: All data uploaded to LabArchives is immediately stored securely at Amazon data centers located in the United States.

instruction: Who can access my data stored in WashU ELN?
output: Only the owner of a lab notebook can determine what is shared, who has access to view their files, and who can edit the files in their notebook. Neither the University nor LabArchives can view your files without your permission.

instruction: With WashU ELN can I collaborate with non-WashU users?
output: Yes, you can collaborate with researchers outside of your lab. As the owner of a lab notebook, you determine who can access and the level of access to your files.

instruction: I already have a LabArchives account associated with my @wustl.edu email address. Can I integrate it with the new WashU ELN service?
output: Yes, check out: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255895/WashU+ELN+FAQ for more information.

instruction: Why should I use WashU ELN instead of OneNote, OneDrive or WUSTL Box?
output: LabArchives is designed to align to lab protocols. Its tools and integrations are built specifically for research and lab activities.

instruction: Does WashU LabArchives support HIPAA data?
output: Yes! LabArchives does indeed have the proper security features to be HIPAA compliant.

instruction: How do I get support for using LabArchives?
output: LabArchives has a robust knowledge base with information for students and instructors. You’ll find answers to most of your questions about the software in the LabArchives Knowledgebase.

instruction: Where can I get a WashU VPN to connect to RIS Services?
output: https://it.wustl.edu/items/connect/

instruction: Where can I read about RIS Storage Volumes
output: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255615/Access+Storage+Volumes

instruction: Can I purchase dedicated scratch or cache space for RIS Compute?
output: Not at this time.

instruction: Can I reserve scratch or cache space for some time for RIS Compute?
output: Not at this time.

instruction: How do I copy data between RIS compute clusters?
output: Visit https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255613/Copying+Data+Between+Compute+Clusters for a step by step guide.

instruction: How do I create a custom Conda environment in RIS Compute?
output: Check out: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184254782/Create+Custom+conda+Environment for a step by step guide.

instruction: How do I see RIS Compute host status?
output: Type bhosts -w once logged in to RIS Compute.

instruction: How do I use CPU resources for RIS Compute?
output: By default, a job will use any CPU that is available to run the job. If a job has specific CPU architecture resource requirements, one can specify a CPU architecture with the rusage expression: > bsub -q foo-condo -R 'select[model==Intel_Xeon_Gold6242CPU280GHz]' -a 'docker(alpine)' /bin/true

instruction: What does the parameter -I mean when running a RIS Compute job?
output: -I submits an interactive job.

instruction: What does the parameter -Ip mean when running a RIS Compute job?
output: -Ip submits an interactive job and creates a pseudo-terminal when the job starts.

instruction: What does the parameter -IS mean when running a RIS Compute job?
output: -IS submits an interactive job under a secure shell (ssh)

instruction: What does the parameter -ISp mean when running a RIS Compute job?
output: -ISp submits an interactive job under a secure shell (ssh) and creates a pseudo-terminal when the job starts.

instruction: What does the parameter -ISs mean when running a RIS Compute job?
output: -ISs submits an interactive job under a secure shell (ssh) and creates a pseudo-terminal with shell mode support when the job starts.

instruction: What does the parameter -Is mean when running a RIS Compute job?
output: -Is submits an interactive job and creates a pseudo-terminal with shell mode when the job starts.

instruction: Is it possible to submit an interactive RIS job within an already interactive RIS job?
output: Yes, however the first job must be started with host networking: LSF_DOCKER_NETWORK=host

instruction: How do I start an interactive job with access to my data on RIS Compute?
output: The current working directory is always mounted by the container automatically, and you can use the LSF_DOCKER_VOLUMES variable to request other volumes to be mounted.

instruction: How do I submit a RIS Compute job to my Condo queue?
output: Add -q labname to your parameters when running bsub to use your allocated Condo.

instruction: How do I choose a host for my RIS Compute job?
output: Use the -m flag to set a specific host: bsub -Is -q general-interactive -m compute1-exec-174...

instruction: How do I assign execution priority for my RIS Compute job?
output: Use the -sp flag to set numeric priority.

instruction: How do I create a job group within RIS Compute?
output: To create a job group and assign it a limit of N running jobs: bgadd -L 10 /${compute_username}/${group_name}

instruction: Why should I make a job group within RIS Compute?
output: It frequently happens that we want to run a resource-intensive process on hundreds or thousands of data sets. In some cases, the load this imposes on the system will become apparent to other users. They will experience increased latency if their data lives on the same filesystem. Using job groups you can create the effect of a personal queue.

instruction: How do I check the status of jobs in my job group within RIS Compute?
output: To check the status of jobs in the job group: bjgroup -s /${compute_username}/${group_name}

instruction: How do I assign jobs to a job group in RIS Compute?
output: Assign jobs to this group at submission time, using -g: bsub -g /${compute_username}/${group_name} -J ${job_name} ...

instruction: How do I list the jobs in a job group in RIS Compute?
output: List jobs in this job group using bjobs: bjobs -g /${compute_username}/${group_name}

instruction: How do I change the number of running jobs in the job group for RIS Compute?
output: Alter the number of running jobs in the job group: bgmod -L 5 /${compute_username}/${group_name}

instruction: Why do I receive notifications for my jobs on RIS Compute?
output: By default, completed jobs will send an email notification to the mail address of the execution $USER. Control this by using the -u command line argument, see man bsub for more about -u.

instruction: What is a .bsub file?
output: The options for the bsub command can be placed within a job file. However, the LSF environment variables will need to be appended either at the beginning of the bsub command to submit the job file or exported prior. The previous options would look like the following within a file named resources_example.bsub: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255619/Job+Execution+Examples.

instruction: How do I submit a job with options using a .bsub file?
output: Given you have your .bsub file, the job is submitted like so: bsub < resources_example.bsub.

instruction: How much memory does my RIS compute job have?
output: The default memory reservation for a compute job is 4GB, and will be killed if it goes over that reservation. One can specify a custom memory reservation with the rusage expression, and the the kill threshold with the -M option.

instruction: How much memory can I request with my RIS Compute job?
output: Try to be as accurate as possible with the memory reservation. Using an artificially high reservation wastes a shared resource, and makes it more difficult to get your job scheduled.

instruction: My RIS Compute job needs a specific CPU architecture. How can I request this?
output: By default, a job will use any CPU that is available to run the job. If a job has specific CPU architecture resource requirements, one can specify a CPU architecture with the rusage expression: bsub -q foo-condo -R 'select[model==Intel_Xeon_Gold6242CPU280GHz]' -a 'docker(alpine)' /bin/true

instruction: What are the current CPU architectures available for RIS Compute?
output: Current CPU architecture available in the general host group: Intel_Xeon_Gold6242CPU280GHz, Intel_Xeon_Gold6148CPU240GHz

instruction: Is there a slot limit for RIS Compute Users?
output: The Compute Platform has a limit of 500 slots per user. This essentially means 500 vCPUs. This is across all jobs. For example, you can have 500 jobs running with 1 vCPU each, or 10 jobs running with 50 vCPUs each, or 1 job running with 500 vCPUs, and if you are using 490 vCPUs and a job you submit needs 15, it will sit in queue until your total is 485 or less.

instruction: How do I use a GPU for my RIS Compute job?
output: To use a GPU, one must include the -gpu flag and the -R 'gpuhost' option as part of the job submission: bsub -q foo-condo -R 'gpuhost' -gpu 'num=1:gmodel=TeslaV100_SXM2_32GB'  -a 'docker(alpine)' /bin/true

instruction: How do I find the current available GPUs for RIS Compute?
output: Type bhosts -gpu -w general. Current GPU models available in the general host group: Double Precision: TeslaV100_SXM2_32GB, NVIDIAA100_SXM4_40GB. Single Precision: NVIDIAA40

instruction: Is there a GPU limit for RIS Compute users?
output: We provide services for the entire WashU campus and as such, we suggest a best practices of not over allocating how many resources a single user utilizes. To that point, we suggest that a single user take up no more than 10 GPUs at a time.

instruction: How do I request more GPU memory for my RIS Compute job?
output: Jobs using GPUs should reserve an appropriate amount of GPU memory with the gmem resource in the -gpu argument. The system will impose a default reservation of 2G if the job submission does not specify something different. For example: -gpu 'num=1:gmem=8G'

instruction: How do I pause specific jobs from a job array in RIS Compute?
output: To stop jobs 10, 20 and 55-65 from the job array named blast_array with ID 456: bstop 'my_array[10, 20, 55-65]'

instruction: How do I kill specific jobs from a job array in RIS Compute?
How do I resume a specific job from a job array in RIS Compute?
output: bresume 'blast_array[10, 20, 55-65]', or bkill -s CONT '456[10, 20, 55-65]'

instruction: How do I see if a given host has enough resources to handle my RIS Compute job?
output: To see which (if any) hosts have enough resources to handle jobs you’d like to submit, use the bhosts -R command. For example, the below query lists all hosts in the foo-condo host group that have at least 25GB of unreserved memory, 25GB of free memory and 10GB of local disk space: bhosts -R 'select[mem>25000 && free_memory_mb>25000 && tmp>10]' foo-condo

instruction: What is the cache for RIS Compute?
output: The cache provides an interface for the batch jobs in the general queue and for condos to the RIS Storage cluster.

instruction: Where is the storage allocation mapped to for RIS Compute?
output: A storage allocation maps to a cache space of the same name at /storage1/fs1/${STORAGE_ALLOCATION}.

instruction: I have a filesystem conflict in my RIS Compute
output: If you encounter a conflict, contact the RIS Service Desk for assistance.

instruction: Can I run interactive and batch jobs for RIS Compute that output to the same directory?
output: No. Given the diffent methods of connecting to the RIS Storage cluster between the client and interactive nodes, and the batch nodes (general queue) and condos, this could lead to filesystem conflicts.

instruction: What is the scratch space for RIS Compute?
output: Scratch space is considered a global temporary space. Users should not store their only copy of data in scratch. Scratch space is available at /scratch1/fs1/${COMPUTE_ALLOCATION}.

instruction: How do I put data into my scratch space for RIS Compute?
output: Data must be manually put into /scratch.

instruction: Is there a storage limit to my RIS scratch space?
output: The /scratch space has quotas set based on compute-group membership (as opposed to fileset quotas, that are in place on storage1). You will have a default quota of 5% of your storage allocation size.

instruction: I can't move any more files into my RIS scratch space
output: Exceeding the quota will trigger a denial after which no further writes will be allowed until your ${COMPUTE_GROUP} removes data and goes below the quota.

instruction: My files are gone from my RIS scratch space
output: Files and directories will be automatically deleted from /scratch when their last modified date (mtime) is older than the LSF job run limit, currently 28 days.

instruction: Is there a cache for my Docker containers for RIS Compute?
output: Docker on each exec host will download images and save them to the exec host's local storage drives, caching them for future docker runs. Old docker containers will be removed after 30 days of inactivity.

instruction: Is there a way to store my envrionment variables for RIS Compute jobs?
output: You can permanently store these settings by including them in your ~/.bashrc file where they will be loaded each time you log in. But be sure to remember that they are there. Historically, users forget what's in their .bashrc, and when systems change, updates to .bashrc may be required. Consider reminding yourself they are present with an 'echo' statement.

instruction:: What is the RIS interactive job command for Anaconda?
output: Using Python 3.5: bsub -G ${group_name} -Is -q general-interactive -a 'docker(continuumio/anaconda3)' /bin/bash. Using Python 2.7: bsub -G ${group_name} -Is -q general-interactive -a 'docker(continuumio/anaconda)' /bin/bash

instruction:: What is the RIS interactive job command for AnnovarR?
output: bsub -G ${group_name} -Is -q general-interactive -a 'docker(bioinstaller/annovarr)' R

instruction: How do I use OFED in Docker images for RIS Compute?

instruction: How do I use CUDA in Docker images for RIS Compute?

instruction: How do I set up my SSH Private-Public Key Pair for RIS Services?
output: Visit this page to learn more about setting up your SSH Key Pair: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184256020/SSH+Private-Public+Key+Pair

instruction: How do I set up Port Forwarding in RIS Compute?

instruction: How do I use parallel computing on a RIS Compute job?
output: Read this documentation to learn more about parallel computing: https://washu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/ITKB/pages/184255617/Parallel+Computing
